Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The three academic divisions that prepare STEM undergraduates and science and
mathematics teachers in the M.A./credential program (MAT) are joining forces with three regional school districts, each with well established teacher induction programs, to build an effective pipeline into mathematics and science teaching jobs in these high-need districts. The partner districts are aiding in the selection of thirty-two STEM majors planning to teach in the areas of specialization that are most needed in their districts.

The Noyce Scholarship Program provides support to: 1) strengthen outreach to and support of a diverse pool of prospective mathematics and science teachers as undergraduates, 2) increase the number and quality of students to be prepared as mathematics and science teachers, 3) further develop close partnerships between the university and regional high-need school districts in order to enhance the recruitment and retention of new teachers in key areas of district shortages, and 4) develop a central piece of work in the dissertation research of a graduate student studying issues of teacher retention and educational policy. Over the course of the project, the Noyce Scholarships are supporting the preparation of 32 new mathematics and science teachers to enter into teaching positions in high-need rural and suburban school districts serving large numbers of low income and English learner students in Santa Cruz and Monterey Counties

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at the University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC) was designed to help recruit and prepare college science and math majors for successful teaching careers and to support them in their early professional lives. It complemented an existing program at UCSC, Cal Teach, which provides coursework for prospective science or math teachers and "field placements" in middle and high school classrooms. The Noyce Scholarship program provided scholarships to enable students to attend a high-quality, but expensive, teacher preparation program at UCSC. This 12-month program provides many months of supported student teaching and leads to an M.A. in Education and a California teaching credential (in California, different from many states, most teachers complete an undergraduate degree and THEN a teacher preparation program). Scholarship support ranged from $16,800 to $24,700 per student, and it typically covered tuition and required fees, but not living expenses, for four of the five academic quarters of the program. In exchange for the scholarship support, Noyce Scholars committed to two years of teaching in a high-need public school within eight years after graduation. Supplemental Noyce funding supported additional activities, summer teaching and laboratory internships for prospective Noyce Scholars. In hopes of recruiting greater numbers of highly-qualified secondary science and math teachers, three high-need school districts within an hour's drive of UCSC signed on as project partners; these partners helped to select Noyce Scholars, and they ultimately hired 40% of the program’s graduates. A research component of this project explored Noyce Scholars’ behavior in a sociological, workforce context, tracking and analyzing the career pathways of the Noyce Scholars and similar peers.

This project supported 32 Noyce Scholars over five academic years. Two did not graduate, and their scholarships were converted to interest-bearing loans, which they are repaying. Of the 30 who graduated, all but one will complete the two years of required teaching service in a high-need school district by spring 2016. The one graduate who has not yet completed his service was initially hired by a private school, which wants to keep him; it is not yet clear if he will transfer to a service-qualifying school or pay back the scholarship. All graduates have had one or more acceptable job offers whenever needed – no one has failed to teach for lack of employment options.

Since the first graduates entered teaching jobs in academic year 2010-11, there has been the potential for 116 person-years of teaching time by the Noyce graduates; 58 person-years were spent fulfilling the required teaching service in high-need schools; another 44.5 person-years have been spent by graduates voluntarily teaching in high-need schools beyond the required service; 8 person-years have been spent teaching in other schools (public schools serving wealthier communities, private religious schools, international schools); and 5.5 years have been spent not teaching for maternity or other temporary reasons. In all, 95% of the 116 person-years since graduation have been spent teaching – none of the 30 graduates has left teaching. Given typical high attrition rates among early career teachers, this is remarkable.

Most teaching by graduates has been in central California schools within 60 miles of Santa Cruz, but one student moved to northern California, another to Los Angeles, one to Maine, and a fourth most recently taught internationally.

The demographics of the 30 new teachers supported by the scholarships follow.

Teaching field: 22 mathematics, 8 science (2 physics, 2 chemistry, 2 Earth science, 2 life science)

Gender: 17 male, 13 female

Ethnicity: 16 White, 9 Latino/a, 3 Asian, 1 African American, 1 Middle Eastern
